segments.text: So what is the status since five years ago with your father?
Five years, my dad was in concentration camp, which was out in the open country and all that, and lived in a shed.
And he had his best friend with him.
So that was one of the good things.
At least they had some friends.
And he would tell us that they would make him
go farm, plant stuff, plant food, chop down trees, you know, very hard thing, carry wood.
Basically, it was just for his own good because he had to do everything for himself.
They did not provide anything.
So in other words, he had to
plant food for him to eat, and also for them to take some, too.
So, in other words, you had to do it for them and for you.

Plant your own shed, and if it gets rotten down by the rain, because they lived five years, it's so long, they had to renew it every time, because they stay there for a long period of time, so they had to rebuild it and all that.
And my grandparents, one time my dad actually knew where he was at.
So my grandparents would go down and would meet him.
And the thing was that when they came down, the land had barbed wires around the place that they were being held.
And there would be a guard escorting you to go in, but not inside past the barbed wire.
You would stay out there, and anybody who wanted to talk to you would come out.
And it's just kind of like a prison where you have a little wall between you, and you have to talk between them.
And it was just like that.
And my grandparents, they were really glad that they see him and all that.
And they did not want you to have a really long meeting, long talk.
So they wanted to make it brief.
And then if you would have it long, they would make you leave and all that.
And so my grandparents did that at least two times the most because they were getting old.
they could not take the long travels and all that.
So they met him twice.
And later on, at the beginning, after that, we thought that the communists, they were getting a little bit easy.
They're getting easy so that they let their families see each other.
But then later on,
We found out that the reason why they wanted us to see him was that he was going to be moved to somewhere else.
And then we would not know where he is at again.
So in other words, we would be back to square one not knowing where he is.
And so a couple months later on,
After my grandparents met him for the last time, and then he stopped sending letters for the last two months and all that.
So my mom wrote a letter back to my grandparents and asked them, what's taking so long?
What happened and all that?
And so she said, there's something wrong.
There's something wrong.
They must be doing something to him.
She has not received letters from him at all and all that.
So we were getting really worried.
We said, uh-oh, looks like they're getting into the tough stuff and all that.
Well, during that time, we didn't know anything.
But then later on, we received his letter.
And he said he don't know where he is.
And he told us that his best friend died because he couldn't handle it anymore.
He was getting real skinny.
Basically,
my dad thought, think that he died, his best friend died because of malnutrition because all they ate was, all they, all the communists gave them was just rice and they were not white rice.
They were, back in the, back in Vietnam you would have two kinds of rice.
There would be white rice for the people to eat and the other rice is red for the
for the pigs to eat, which is kind of like barley or oats or something like that.
And so they would feed you red rice.
That's what we called it.
They would feed you red rice, and that was it.
You had your own food and all that.
So basically, they ate rice plain or rice with salt every day.
If you would not eat, you would starve.
My dad said that's probably one reason why his best friend died.
Another thing was too much pressure.
He was going crazy because he was missing his families and all that.
So we were real sad and all that.
And then my mom asked if he was all right because my dad had a problem with his health.
Whenever he would go to the bathroom, whenever he would go to the bathroom, he would be bleeding.
He would be bleeding.
That was my mom's real concern.
My mom's real concern was that because they did not
provide toilet paper for him so that he would have to use leaves to wipe, you know, to clean.
So if he did that, he would have disease and, you know, it would be infected and they would not provide doctors for them for him to be nursed and all that.

So, you know, that, because right after when my mom said that his best friend died, my mom started to get worried because, you know, she said, and then she was also thinking that maybe they're going to keep them as long as, until they die.
But then, after that, we found out that one of my dad's uncle, who was in the army, and he was not an officer, but he was kind of like a well-known soldier before, because...
at the beginning of the war, he went to fight.
And he had a very good record of killing a lot of communists.
So when he was being taken, they tortured him.
They pulled out all of his teeth, trying to ask him questions like, how did you kill the communists?
How many did you kill?
And all that.
And so he would not answer.
And they would torture him.
They would beat him up, break his legs, break his arm.
And he would be all bruised.
His face would be all bruised and all that, broken ribs and all that.
But then we found out that he was being released.
So he went home.
And the thing about the communists was that when they release somebody, they don't let you know.
They do not.
inform the family so that the family could come and pick him up.
They did not let you know.
So my uncle went home.
He told us, he said that one day they just say, OK, you're free to go.
And they just opened the gate.
And he was left all out by himself.
And so he had nowhere to go because it was right out in the open country.
He started to go walking down the street, and then he stopped by a place where a stranger, where this farm family lived.
And he did not know them, but he asked them if they could help him to contact his family and all that.
And then later on, he went home, and his wife was just shocked that he was standing right in front of her because he...

She did not get any contact that he was being released, but she was real happy that he was there and in and she was happy and she was sad because He looked like he was gonna die because he was in such a bad shape But later on they nursed him and all that and he was all right and so
Basically, everybody from my mom's side and my dad's side were, was being released, except for my dad.
He was the only one left in there, and, uh,
Was he tortured in any way?
He said that he did not get tortured.
He said that they... Well, I don't know if he did or not because if he would have said it, they would have erased it.
But we would assume that he wasn't because, by the way, of his handwriting.
My mom...
and my grandmother, they would take an assumption that his handwriting looks normal as usual.
So his health must be real fine, because he said he's doing all right and all that.
And so after two months, they received his letter.
And then he told them, he said that he's been moved to another place out in the country.
And he would not know where he's at again.
And that was the last letter.
And then two more years passed.
And then my mom started getting to worry because my mom started to say, oh, no, this is it.
There's no way they're going to let him out at all now.
And for the whole next year, for the whole year, for one whole year at one time, we would not receive any letters, anything from him.
The next day, you know, and then one day, he would, we would receive his letter, and he would say that,
He was moved to another place again.
And so my grandparents wanted to come and visit him, but my mom told them not to because for one reason was their health.
They had to be healthy in order for them to keep the contact going.
That's one reason.
And the other reason was it was useless for you to go because you would not know where he's at because they kept on moving him.
So why should you go see him for him?
And so, and then after seven years, seven and a half years, my dad wrote another letter saying that they're going to let him go.
And so at that time, my mom was real happy, was really happy.
We were all happy.
The neighborhood was happy because they actually, you know, they kind of like knew the news because
Everybody was being released around the neighborhood except for him.
So, you know, the people would come and ask, you know, has he been released yet and all that?
How long is he going to be released?
And so one day he was released.
And I guess he was so important that they did not let him go by himself.
They actually drove him home.
They drove him home.
He had the same luggages that my mom had packed for him.
And he stayed in the house.
And later on, the first couple of days, we thought that he was already free and all that.
But then later on, a couple of days later, my grandmother, when she'd go shopping, go grocery and all that,
she would find out that there would be at least two or three guys hanging around the house, the front yard of the house, the backyard of the house, the front door, the back door, and all that.
They were practically around the house so that they would keep an eye on him, where he would go and all that.
And so after that, my grandmother would go back inside and told him not to go anywhere, told him to stay inside because they're out there.
They're out there just looking after him.
And he stayed home for one month.
And they took him again.
And it was just the same old procedure.
One day, they would come.
They would make up an excuse.
They would say, OK, we need to ask you some questions.
So we need to take you to a certain place.
And at that time, you know,
My grandmother knew that we should not trust them at all now because the last time they did it to all the other people, all the other people were shocked.
They said that it was a meeting, but it wasn't.
It was actually taking everybody to the concentration camp.
So now my grandmother knew that they're taking him again.
So he was just right back in the concentration camp again.
Right, but this time they did not tell him where he's at and all that.
And so he was taken out again and no letters for a couple of months again.
And then another day, receive a letter saying that he's fine and he's at another place and all that.
And then he would stay for another...
for another two years.
So that would make it nine and a half years.
He would stay for another two years.
And then they released him again.
In what year was this?
This was, he was taken in 76.
So in around, in the 85, September of 85 or something like that.
He was being released, and my grandmother and him talked and all that.
Then later on, he told them, my grandmother wrote a letter to my mom and all that.
And then we found out that that last two years, he was right inside Saigon.
They kept him right in the cities.
So in other words, he did, that whole two years, we did not receive a single letter
because they were so close in, so they did not want him to write letters.
So he was not out in the countryside anymore.
So that two years, he was in a penitentiary that was in Saigon.
And then my mom thought, oh, no, they're going to take him out away again for a couple more months.
But then later on, we found out the first couple of weeks when he was home, they looked over him.
But then later on, they started to back off.
And then my grandmother said, think that it was OK.
So he started to go out, taking contact, start the escape as fast as possible.
But the problem was that we were running out of time because when my dad was still in concentration camp, my mom wrote a letter.
During that two years, my mom wrote a letter to my grandmother saying that, OK, it's getting hopeless now.
So if you two want to go over here with us, why don't you go ahead and make paper?
Because at that time, the government of the communists, the communist government, agreed to release all of the handicapped people, all the old people,
and all of the Asian-American kids to go free as they choose.
And so at that time, my grandfather quickly made paper for them to leave.
For your grandparents to leave.
Right, for my grandparents to leave.
So in other words, my dad, if he would get released, he would be by himself.
So your grandparents are over here now?
Right.
My grandparents just got over here last December, which was 85, December of 85.
And so the paper was being done and there were two ways for them to come over.
One was go straight to United States or the other go to Canada.
Canada is partly French.
And so my grandfather was really connected with the French.
So he wanted to go real fast, really fast.
He didn't want any delay.
And another thing was Canada was more lenient than the United States at that time because it was so late.
They were getting very hard for you to come in.
And so we told them to go to Canada and then from Canada make the paper to go to the United States.
And so that's what they did.
And it did not take them that long at all.
So your father was by yourself?
Yes.
When my father was released, they were still with him, but they told him what they did, and he said it was fine, you know.
And then later on, we found out that it was fine because he was being released for real now, you know.
And so he was out making contact, out meeting all the relatives and the neighbors and all that, and making contact.
And then later on,
My mom wrote another letter saying that and you know they wrote letter back and forth and back and forth and then later on they came to an agreement to let's drop
the plan for him to escape by boat because it was getting too late.
It was 1985.
And by that time, it would be too dangerous.
And if he would get caught, they would probably kill him right there.
And so they dropped the plan.
And they said, now the government has this new plan
for you to go by paper where you would get on an airplane and you would fly.
And so we agreed that that would be the plan.
But then the only setback that we had was if you go by boat, it would be faster for you to come over.
If you go by the paper, it would take so many process
from the government of the United States and the government of the North Vietnamese that it would take so long that we would not know how long he would be in order for him to come over.
And so, but we were all willing to sacrifice the long period of time instead.
For safety.
Yes, for safety.
So on December, my grandparents
had their name on the list and they left.
And at that time, my dad was in good health, in good condition already.
So he was basically, he was, could be on his, he could be on his own already.
So my mom was really happy, you know, and all that because we were really happy when they, when he, when he came back, that was the only thing.
And so,
Have y'all filed the paperwork for your father?
Yes.
Right after my mom found out the news that we could do it by the paperwork, she did it right away.
In fact, she did it for my grandparents also.
She did it for my grandparents, and then she mailed it to my aunt from Canada.
She thought that...
It would take my dad that just that short of a time to go because it took my grandparents only four months.
No, actually it took them.
Yeah, it took them four months and they were, they were already out.
But, uh, right after my dad came back, she started on it right away and now it's still going on.
And, uh, uh, you know, once a month we would contact the attorney.
that did the paperwork for us, saying how long more and all that.
And they would make some excuses.
They would say that there's probably something wrong with it, or they're holding back the processes or something like that.
Or they would blame it on the North Vietnamese that they're holding back on the processes.
They're trying to slow it down and all that.
So the paper is still in order right now.
I don't know how long it's gonna be until my dad comes over, but at least the papers are in.
My mom said that

But we, our paper is much faster than other people because we had, when we came over here, we had a couple of friends that also had, you know, my friend, my mom, yeah, my mom's friend, you know, her husband was also in concentration camp.
And so she did that paper and all that, and she said that it took,
that she is still on the waiting, you know, she is not even on the waiting list.
And we were on the waiting list, but the waiting list is really long.
It's a very long list.
And especially my dad is a special, a special case so that they would have to take a really deep, you know, good deal of look and decision on whether if he is, if they're gonna let him go or not.
Yeah.
